citations.narrative:
A wooden kennel door on the back side of the main outdoor area is broken at the base corner of the door creating a gap
under the wire mesh. This door needs to be repaired to adequately contain the dog for its safety.
Correct by: July 28, 2025

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
** Enclosures are still not being spot cleaned daily. There was evidence of feces in multiple indoor boxes that need to be
removed in both the whelping room and main kennel and the color and amount of feces indicated that it is not being done
daily. Additionally, there were feces that is not falling through the wire mesh portion of the runs that also needs to be
removed.
** A few of the sheltered box style enclosures had an accumulation of food waste that was on the floor also not being
removed through daily spot cleaning.
Fecal and food waste must be removed from primary enclosures daily to prevent soiling of the dogs and reduce odors.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
** Primary enclosures are still not being cleaned and sanitized at least once every two weeks. There is a buildup of hair
hanging down from the wood support beams in the whelping room that contains shavings. This accumulation of shavings
hair traps urine, dust and debris in and around the primary enclosures which can contribute to a strong odor of ammonia
in and around the whelping room.
** In the main kennel the sheltered box style enclosure has an accumulation of grime along the stainless-steel shift doors
that are not being cleaned and the floors have excess shavings and feces underneath crates and buckets placed in the
box that are not being cleaned.
These primary enclosures must be cleaned and sanitized at least once every two weeks for the health of the dogs.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
**Housekeeping in the whelping room and in the main kennel needs to be addressed. In the whelping room, there is still a
layer of dust and debris along the door frames and tops of enclosures. The window stills in the whelping room have an
abundance of dead flies that are not being removed.
**There are multiple empty enclosures with food receptacles containing food that is now caked with dust or have
remnants of mouse droppings in the receptacles in both the whelpling room and main kennel area. These empty
enclosures also contain feces that were never removed or cleaned.
These empty enclosures are adjacent to enclosures containing dogs and need to be kept clean to facilitate good
housekeeping practices for the overall health of the dogs in the whelping room.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.1(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
A wooden kennel door on the back side of the main outdoor area is broken at the base corner of the door creating a gap 
under the wire mesh. This door needs to be repaired to adequately contain the dog for its safety. 
Correct by: July 28, 2025 
3.11(a)  Repeat
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
** Enclosures are still not being spot cleaned daily. There was evidence of feces in multiple indoor boxes that need to be 
removed in both the whelping room and main kennel and the color and amount of feces indicated that it is not being done 
daily. Additionally, there were feces that is not falling through the wire mesh portion of the runs that also needs to be 
removed.  
 
** A few of the sheltered box style enclosures had an accumulation of food waste that was on the floor also not being 
removed through daily spot cleaning.  
 
Fecal and food waste must be removed from primary enclosures daily to prevent soiling of the dogs and reduce odors. 
3.11(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
** Primary enclosures are still not being cleaned and sanitized at least once every two weeks. There is a buildup of hair 
hanging down from the wood support beams in the whelping room that contains shavings. This accumulation of shavings 
hair traps urine, dust and debris in and around the primary enclosures which can contribute to a strong odor of ammonia 
in and around the whelping room. 
 
** In the main kennel the sheltered box style enclosure has an accumulation of grime along the stainless-steel shift doors 
that are not being cleaned and the floors have excess shavings and feces underneath crates and buckets placed in the 
box that are not being cleaned.  
 
These primary enclosures must be cleaned and sanitized at least once every two weeks for the health of the dogs.

3.11(c)  Repeat
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
**Housekeeping in the whelping room and in the main kennel needs to be addressed. In the whelping room, there is still a 
layer of dust and debris along the door frames and tops of enclosures. The window stills in the whelping room have an 
abundance of dead flies that are not being removed.  
 
**There are multiple empty enclosures with food receptacles containing food that is now caked with dust or have 
remnants of mouse droppings in the receptacles in both the whelpling room and main kennel area. These empty 
enclosures also contain feces that were never removed or cleaned.  
These empty enclosures are adjacent to enclosures containing dogs and need to be kept clean to facilitate good 
housekeeping practices for the overall health of the dogs in the whelping room. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
